body.p: Robertson AE, Hyatt K, Kenkel C, Hanson K, Myers DA. Interleukin 1β Regulates Progesterone Metabolism in Human Cervical Fibroblasts. Reproductive Sciences. 2012;19:271-281. (Original DOI: 10.1177/1933719111419246)
On page 280 of the March 2012 issue of Reproductive Sciences, the following should have been inserted as Figure 9:

caption.p: The increased progesterone reduction in response to IL-1β is due to increased AKR activity. Cellular extracts were prepared from human cervical fibroblasts treated with IL-1β or vehicle for 24 hours. The AKR activity was determined in the presence of (A) 10 µmol/L meclofenamic acid (AKR1C inhibitor), (B) 5 mmol/L fenasteride (5α reductase inhibitor), or (C) both meclofenamic acid and fenasteride as determined by spectrophotometric (340 nm) analysis of oxidation of NADPH (200 µmol/L) in the presence of 50 mmol/L progesterone as described in Methods section using cellular extracts (100 µg) obtained from control cells or cells treated with IL-1β for 24 hours. A representative reaction is shown from 3 independent experiments. AKR indicates aldo-keto reductase; IL-1β, interleukin 1β; NADPH, nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide phosphate.
